newsitem.title: USA: Senate backs bill on birth defect prevention.
newsitem.headline: Senate backs bill on birth defect prevention.

text.p: The Senate by a voice vote Thursday backed a bill to monitor birth defects and sponsor research and public awareness programmes to try to prevent them.

About 150,000 U.S. babies are born with serious birth defects each year and they are the leading cause of infant deaths. Causes include genetic defects, exposure to environmental hazards and complications during pregnancy.

The bill backs efforts to increase public awareness of two ways to avoid birth defects -- taking folic acid vitamin supplements early in pregnancy to prevent spina bifida and avoiding alcohol during pregnancy to prevent Foetal Alcohol Syndrome.

The bill establishes regional birth defects research programmes, aimed in part at studying regional clusters of defects. It also sets up a National Information Clearinghouse on Birth Defects to collect and disseminate information to health professionals and to the public.
It allocates $30 million for fiscal 1998 and $40 million for 1999.
